metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Factors affecting the frequency and success of reactant particle collisions and the rate of a chemical reaction in open and closed systems, including temperature, surface area, concentration, gas pressures, presence of a catalyst, activation energy and orientation

collision_theory_basics.name: Collision Theory Fundamentals
collision_theory_basics.formula: Collide + Sufficient Energy + Correct Orientation = Reaction
collision_theory_basics.correct: For a reaction to occur, particles must collide with sufficient energy (â‰¥ activation energy) AND in the correct orientation.

particles just need to collide.error: Collision alone is not enough for a reaction.
particles just need to collide.fix: Collisions must also have enough energy AND correct orientation. Many collisions are unsuccessful.
particles just need to collide.action: Think of a key in a lock: you need the right key (orientation) AND enough force to turn it (energy).

all collisions result in products.fix: Only collisions with both sufficient energy AND correct orientation form products.
all collisions result in products.action: In gases, molecules collide billions of times per second but most just bounce off.

energy is the only requirement.error: Orientation matters tooâ€”even high-energy collisions can fail.
energy is the only requirement.fix: Molecules must align correctly for bonds to form. Wrong orientation = unsuccessful collision.
energy is the only requirement.action: Like catching a ball: you need to be facing the right way, not just have your hands out.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the three requirements for a successful collision.
persistent.action: Draw the four collision outcomes: sufficient/insufficient energy Ã— correct/incorrect orientation.

activation_energy.name: Activation Energy
activation_energy.correct: Activation energy (Ea) is the MINIMUM energy that colliding particles must have for a reaction to occur. It represents the energy barrier that must be overcome.

the energy released by the reaction.error: That's enthalpy change (Î”H), not activation energy.
the energy released by the reaction.fix: Ea is the energy INPUT needed to start. Î”H is the overall energy change.
the energy released by the reaction.action: A match needs energy to strike (Ea) before it releases heat (Î”H).

the total energy of the products.error: Ea is about the barrier, not final energy.
the total energy of the products.fix: Ea is the 'hill' reactants must climb. Product energy is where they end up.
the total energy of the products.action: Look at an energy profile: Ea is the peak height above reactants.

the average kinetic energy of particles.error: Average energy is different from the minimum required.
the average kinetic energy of particles.fix: Ea is a threshold. Many particles have less energy, some have more.
the average kinetic energy of particles.action: In a Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution, only particles to the RIGHT of Ea can react.

persistent.gap: You're confusing activation energy with other energy terms.
persistent.action: Draw an energy profile and label Ea, Î”H, reactant energy, and product energy separately.

orientation_requirement.name: Orientation Requirement
orientation_requirement.formula: Correct alignment needed for bond formation
orientation_requirement.correct: Particles must collide in the correct orientation (alignment) so that new bonds can form. Incorrect orientation means reactants just bounce off each other.

any collision angle works.error: Angle and alignment matter for bond formation.
any collision angle works.fix: Atoms must approach so that reacting parts can interact. Wrong angle = no reaction.
any collision angle works.action: Think of puzzle pieces: they only fit one way, no matter how hard you push.

only energy matters.error: High energy with wrong orientation still fails.
only energy matters.fix: Both correct orientation AND sufficient energy are needed. Missing either = no reaction.
only energy matters.action: A fast-moving key hitting a lock sideways won't open it.

orientation only matters for solids.error: All particles need correct orientation, including gases and liquids.
orientation only matters for solids.fix: Gas molecules especially collide in random orientations, making many collisions unsuccessful.
orientation only matters for solids.action: Gases have freedom to rotate and tumble, so correct orientation is often by chance.

persistent.gap: You underestimate the importance of molecular orientation.
persistent.action: Draw two molecules colliding in correct vs incorrect orientations. Show why only one works.

concentration_effect.name: Concentration and Rate
concentration_effect.formula: â†‘ Concentration â†’ â†‘ Collision frequency â†’ â†‘ Rate
concentration_effect.correct: Increasing concentration increases the collision frequency (more particles per unit volume = more collisions), which increases the rate of reaction.

increases the energy of particles.fix: Concentration affects HOW OFTEN particles collide, not HOW HARD. Energy comes from temperature.
increases the energy of particles.action: More people in a room = more bumping, but not harder bumping.

lowers the activation energy.error: Ea is fixed for a reactionâ€”concentration can't change it.
lowers the activation energy.fix: Concentration increases collision frequency. Only catalysts lower Ea.
lowers the activation energy.action: The energy barrier stays the same; there are just more attempts to overcome it.

improves the orientation of collisions.error: Orientation is random and unaffected by concentration.
improves the orientation of collisions.fix: More collisions occur, but the proportion with correct orientation stays the same.
improves the orientation of collisions.action: Doubling concentration doubles collisions but doesn't change collision geometry.

persistent.gap: You don't understand that concentration only affects collision frequency.
persistent.action: Complete the table: concentration affects frequency (yes/no), energy (yes/no), orientation (yes/no).

gas_pressure_effect.name: Gas Pressure and Rate
gas_pressure_effect.formula: â†‘ Pressure (â†“ Volume) â†’ â†‘ Collision frequency â†’ â†‘ Rate
gas_pressure_effect.correct: Increasing gas pressure (or decreasing volume) forces particles closer together, increasing collision frequency and thus the rate of reaction.

increases particle energy.error: Pressure doesn't change kinetic energyâ€”that's temperature.
increases particle energy.fix: Pressure brings particles closer, increasing collisions. Energy stays the same.
increases particle energy.action: Compressing a gas makes particles bump more often, not more energetically.

changes the activation energy.fix: Pressure only affects how often particles meet, not the energy barrier.
changes the activation energy.action: The reaction pathway is the same; particles just encounter each other more frequently.

only affects liquids.error: Pressure effects are most significant for gases.
only affects liquids.fix: Liquids and solids are nearly incompressible. Gas volume changes dramatically with pressure.
only affects liquids.action: Halving the volume of a gas doubles the pressure and collision frequency.

persistent.gap: You're confusing pressure effects with temperature or catalyst effects.
persistent.action: Draw particles in a large vs small container. Same energy, different collision frequency.

surface_area_effect.name: Surface Area and Rate
surface_area_effect.formula: â†‘ Surface area â†’ â†‘ Collision frequency â†’ â†‘ Rate
surface_area_effect.correct: Increasing surface area exposes more particles to react, increasing collision frequency. Smaller particle size = larger total surface area.

increases the energy of particles.error: Surface area doesn't affect particle energy.
increases the energy of particles.fix: More surface = more particles available to collide. Energy is unchanged.
increases the energy of particles.action: Cutting a solid into pieces exposes more particles but doesn't heat them.

only the outside particles can react.error: This is actually correctâ€”that's WHY surface area matters.
only the outside particles can react.fix: Interior particles are trapped. Increasing surface area exposes more to collisions.
only the outside particles can react.action: This is why powders react faster than lumpsâ€”more particles are on the outside.

affects reactions in solution.error: Surface area mainly affects heterogeneous reactions (solid with liquid/gas).
affects reactions in solution.fix: In solution, particles are already dispersed. Surface area matters for solids.
affects reactions in solution.action: Dissolving a solid eliminates surface area effectsâ€”all particles are exposed.

persistent.gap: You don't visualise why surface area matters at the particle level.
persistent.action: Draw a cube vs 8 smaller cubes from the same material. Count exposed particles.

temperature_effect.name: Temperature and Rate
temperature_effect.formula: â†‘ Temperature â†’ â†‘ Collision frequency + â†‘ Successful collisions â†’ â†‘ Rate
temperature_effect.correct: Increasing temperature increases BOTH collision frequency (particles move faster) AND the proportion of collisions with energy â‰¥ Ea.

only increases collision frequency.error: Temperature has a dual effectâ€”it also increases collision energy.
only increases collision frequency.fix: Faster particles collide more often AND harder. Both effects increase rate.
only increases collision frequency.action: Hot particles move faster (more collisions) and hit harder (more energy per collision).

lowers the activation energy.error: Ea stays the sameâ€”more particles just exceed it.
lowers the activation energy.fix: Temperature shifts the Maxwell-Boltzmann curve so more particles have E â‰¥ Ea.
lowers the activation energy.action: The hurdle (Ea) is the same height; more runners can jump it.

only affects gases.error: Temperature affects all states of matter.
only affects gases.fix: Particles in solids, liquids, and gases all gain kinetic energy when heated.
only affects gases.action: Cooking, metabolism, corrosionâ€”all speed up with temperature regardless of state.

persistent.gap: You only know one of temperature's two effects on rate.
persistent.action: Explain both: (1) faster movement = more collisions, (2) higher energy = more successful.

maxwell_boltzmann.name: Maxwell-Boltzmann Distribution
maxwell_boltzmann.formula: Distribution of particle energies in a sample
maxwell_boltzmann.correct: The Maxwell-Boltzmann curve shows the distribution of kinetic energies in a sample. Higher temperatures shift the curve right, putting more particles above Ea.

all particles have the same energy.error: Particles have a RANGE of energies at any temperature.
all particles have the same energy.fix: Some particles are slow, most are medium, some are fast. It's a distribution.
all particles have the same energy.action: Like heights in a classâ€”there's a range, not one value.

the curve shows concentration.error: The curve shows energy distribution, not concentration.
the curve shows concentration.fix: Y-axis is proportion of particles; X-axis is kinetic energy.
the curve shows concentration.action: It answers: what fraction of particles have this energy?

higher temperature makes a taller peak.error: Higher temperature makes a lower, broader peak shifted right.
higher temperature makes a taller peak.fix: Area under the curve stays constant (same number of particles). It spreads and flattens.
higher temperature makes a taller peak.action: Total particles conserved; they just spread across a wider energy range.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how to read Maxwell-Boltzmann curves.
persistent.action: Sketch curves for T1 and T2 (T2 > T1). Mark Ea and shade the particles that can react.

catalyst_definition.name: Catalyst Definition
catalyst_definition.formula: Lowers Ea via alternative pathway; not consumed
catalyst_definition.correct: A catalyst increases reaction rate by providing an alternative reaction pathway with LOWER activation energy. The catalyst is not consumed in the reaction.

provides energy to the reaction.error: Catalysts don't add energyâ€”they lower the energy barrier.
provides energy to the reaction.fix: Catalysts make the reaction easier by offering a different route, not by adding energy.
provides energy to the reaction.action: A tunnel through a mountain vs climbing over itâ€”same destination, easier path.

is used up during the reaction.error: Catalysts are regenerated and can be reused.
is used up during the reaction.fix: A catalyst participates then returns to original form. It's not consumed.
is used up during the reaction.action: Enzymes catalyse millions of reactions without being used up.

increases the energy of particles.error: That's what temperature does, not catalysts.
increases the energy of particles.fix: Catalyst lowers Ea so MORE existing particles have sufficient energy.
increases the energy of particles.action: Same particle energies, but the hurdle is now lower.

changes the products formed.error: Catalysts speed up reactions but don't change what's produced.
changes the products formed.fix: Products are identical; they're just formed faster.
changes the products formed.action: Same equation, same Î”H, just faster.

persistent.gap: You're confusing catalysts with reactants or with temperature effects.
persistent.action: Complete: Catalyst lowers ___. Temperature increases ___. Both increase ___.

catalyst_types.name: Homogeneous vs Heterogeneous Catalysts
catalyst_types.correct: Homogeneous catalysts are in the SAME phase as reactants. Heterogeneous catalysts are in a DIFFERENT phase (e.g., solid catalyst with liquid reactants).

homogeneous means one catalyst.error: Homogeneous refers to phase, not quantity.
homogeneous means one catalyst.fix: Homo = same. Homogeneous catalyst = same phase as reactants.
homogeneous means one catalyst.action: An aqueous catalyst with aqueous reactants is homogeneous.

heterogeneous means mixed products.error: Heterogeneous refers to catalyst phase, not product mixture.
heterogeneous means mixed products.fix: Hetero = different. Heterogeneous = catalyst in different phase from reactants.
heterogeneous means mixed products.action: Solid platinum catalysing gas reactions is heterogeneous.

only homogeneous catalysts work.error: Both types are widely used and effective.
only homogeneous catalysts work.fix: Heterogeneous often preferred industriallyâ€”easier to separate from products.
only homogeneous catalysts work.action: Car catalytic converters use solid catalysts (heterogeneous) for exhaust gases.

persistent.gap: You confuse homogeneous/heterogeneous catalysts with equilibria.
persistent.action: Give one example each: homogeneous catalyst, heterogeneous catalyst.

open_closed_systems.name: Open vs Closed Systems
open_closed_systems.formula: Matter exchange allowed vs not allowed
open_closed_systems.correct: In an open system, matter can enter or leave. In a closed system, matter cannot enter or leave but energy can. Rate factors apply to both systems.

rate factors only work in closed systems.error: Rate factors work in both open and closed systems.
rate factors only work in closed systems.fix: Temperature, concentration, etc. affect rate regardless of system type.
rate factors only work in closed systems.action: Cooking in an open pan (open system) still speeds up with heat.

closed means nothing can enter or leave.error: Closed means matter can't leave; energy still can.
closed means nothing can enter or leave.fix: Closed â‰  isolated. You can heat a sealed flask.
closed means nothing can enter or leave.action: A sealed container you can warm up is closed but not isolated.

only closed systems have reactions.error: Reactions occur in both open and closed systems.
only closed systems have reactions.fix: Open systems have reactions tooâ€”products may escape but reactions still occur.
only closed systems have reactions.action: Combustion in open air is a reaction in an open system.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the difference between open, closed, and isolated systems.
persistent.action: Define each system type. Give a reaction example for open and closed.

collision_theory_basics.title: Collision Theory Fundamentals
collision_theory_basics.content: Collision theory explains how chemical reactions occur at the molecular level. For a reaction to happen, particles must: (1) collide with each other, (2) have sufficient energy (â‰¥ activation energy), and (3) be in the correct orientation. Most collisions are unsuccessful because one or both of these conditions are not met.
keyPoints: Three requirements: collision, sufficient energy, correct orientation
Most collisions are unsuccessful
All three conditions must be met simultaneously
Four possible outcomes: 2 energy levels Ã— 2 orientations

activation_energy.title: Activation Energy (Ea)
activation_energy.content: Activation energy is the minimum energy that colliding particles must possess for a reaction to occur. It represents the energy barrier between reactants and products. On an energy profile diagram, Ea is the height from the reactant energy level to the peak of the curve.
keyPoints: Ea = minimum energy for reaction
Shown as height to peak on energy profile
Different from enthalpy change (Î”H)
Can be lowered by catalysts

orientation_requirement.title: Orientation Requirement
orientation_requirement.content: Even when particles collide with sufficient energy, they must also be aligned correctly for bonds to form. The reacting parts of molecules must be facing each other. Incorrect orientation results in particles simply bouncing off each other.
keyPoints: Correct alignment needed for bond formation
Like a key fitting into a lock
Gases especially prone to incorrect orientations
Cannot be improved by concentration or pressure

concentration_effect.title: Concentration and Reaction Rate
concentration_effect.content: Increasing concentration increases the number of particles per unit volume, which increases collision frequency. More collisions per second means more opportunities for successful reactions. Concentration does NOT affect particle energy or orientation.
keyPoints: â†‘ Concentration â†’ â†‘ Collision frequency â†’ â†‘ Rate
Does NOT affect particle energy
Does NOT affect orientation
Works by increasing number of collisions, not their success rate

gas_pressure_effect.title: Gas Pressure and Reaction Rate
gas_pressure_effect.content: Increasing pressure (or decreasing volume) forces gas particles closer together, increasing collision frequency. This is similar to the concentration effect but achieved by reducing space rather than adding particles. Most significant for gas-phase reactions.
keyPoints: â†‘ Pressure â†’ â†“ Volume â†’ â†‘ Collision frequency
Same effect as concentrationâ€”more collisions
Does NOT affect particle energy
Most significant for gases (liquids/solids are incompressible)

surface_area_effect.title: Surface Area and Reaction Rate
surface_area_effect.content: Increasing surface area exposes more particles on the outside of a solid to collisions with other reactants. Only particles on the surface can react; interior particles are trapped. Powders have more surface area than lumps of the same mass.
keyPoints: Only surface particles can react
Smaller pieces = larger total surface area
Important for heterogeneous reactions (solid + liquid/gas)
Powders react faster than lumps

temperature_effect.title: Temperature and Reaction Rate
temperature_effect.content: Temperature is unique because it has TWO effects on rate: (1) faster-moving particles collide more frequently, and (2) a greater proportion of particles have energy â‰¥ Ea. The Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution shows how temperature shifts the energy distribution.
keyPoints: DUAL effect: more collisions AND more successful collisions
Increases kinetic energy of particles
Shifts Maxwell-Boltzmann curve right
Does NOT lower Eaâ€”just puts more particles above it

maxwell_boltzmann.title: Maxwell-Boltzmann Distribution
maxwell_boltzmann.content: This curve shows the distribution of kinetic energies among particles in a sample. At higher temperatures, the curve becomes flatter and broader, shifting to the right. The area under the curve (total particles) stays constant, but more particles have energy above Ea.
keyPoints: Shows distribution of particle energies
Higher T â†’ flatter, broader curve shifted right
Area under curve = total particles (constant)
Particles to the right of Ea can react

catalyst_definition.title: How Catalysts Work
catalyst_definition.content: Catalysts increase reaction rate by providing an alternative pathway with lower activation energy. They are not consumed in the reaction and do not change the products or Î”H. On a Maxwell-Boltzmann curve, adding a catalyst moves the Ea line left, so more particles can react.
keyPoints: Provides alternative pathway with lower Ea
Not consumedâ€”can be reused
Same products and same Î”H
Moves Ea line left on Maxwell-Boltzmann curve

catalyst_types.title: Types of Catalysts
catalyst_types.content: Homogeneous catalysts are in the same phase as reactants (e.g., aqueous catalyst for aqueous reactants). Heterogeneous catalysts are in a different phase (e.g., solid platinum for gas reactions). Heterogeneous catalysts are often preferred industrially because they're easier to separate from products.
keyPoints: Homogeneous = same phase as reactants
Heterogeneous = different phase from reactants
Heterogeneous easier to separate from products
Both lower Ea equally effectively

open_closed_systems.title: Open vs Closed Systems
open_closed_systems.content: In an open system, matter can enter or leave. In a closed system, matter cannot cross the boundary but energy can. Rate factors (temperature, concentration, etc.) work in both system types. Closed systems are needed for equilibrium but not for reactions to occur.
keyPoints: Open: matter can enter/leave
Closed: matter trapped, energy can flow
Rate factors work in both systems
Reactions occur in both open and closed systems
